Notice: Played a lot more before Steam release.

I checked out Eden Star way back when it was a tech demo, it had its ups and downs, and seeing it still alive and kicking is always awesome. It was using the Unreal Engine 3, and now they're using the Unreal Engine 4, but did it change much in terms of how it plays out? only a tiny bit.

This is their very first release of the game to the public (aside from that tech demo), which is really early, where you go and build an 'Eden' which protects you from the night damaging atmosphere, and it's also your main point of where you can construct structures, weapons, tools, and powers. And you have to protect it from the creatures it lures in the night, by constructing defenses (walls), turrets to shoot them, guns for you to shoot them, and new powers to destroy them, OR use your telekinetic melee powers to hold them, and then smash them in the direction of you choosing, to the closest hard object that will deal massive damage.

That's the game at the moment, gather resources, build stuff, protect and attack, but how good is it? well to me, it has the good looks, although a higher field of vision would help in making the world feel bigger, it's relatively easy to get into and have a good game going with how simple you get the resources, and then craft the structures you want, but all that is low in performance to what I think the game does extremely well, and that is its melee combat system with how amazing awesome it plays out, and that's what lured me to the game in the first place.

The developers really have a great thing going on Eden Star with its satisfying melee combat system, keep on improving it, making it more awesome with a lot of more fun way to go on wrecking havoc on enemies with it, and honestly without that combat system, the game would be another survival horde mode type of game, so keep on improving and adding on on that combat system devs!

But at the current moment of the game, is it worth playing it? it depends. If you think it looks cool and really want to try it out, sure go ahead, but how I see it, the game will be at its finest when it's out, or near release out of development, with a good story and progression to go along with it. I see this as a structured sand'boxed' experience, with a path drawn for you to walk in, but that path is really wide for you to move around comfortably. So again, if you want to check it out, go ahead, but if you want the experience that the developers (I would presume) want you to play through, then I'd advise of waiting for the release.

Early Access Review

Currently, Eden Star is a game with some incredibly amusing concepts, great visuals and suprising amounts of polish considering its an Early Access tittle still being in early alpha. Currently, the main aspect of the game is building and protecting a base in a tower defense esque setting. Starting out, you will spawn in a pretty small world of floating isles, having the ability to collect resources trying to set up a small base before the first night. You do so using a system reminiscent of Rust or Ark: Survival Evolved which is quite well implemented in this game. You will be able to roam the world using the suprisingly competent parkour movement, avoiding being mauled by enemies roaming the world. On your travels you will be able to harvest resources that can be used to build up your base and craft new gear for your character. Af it stands, the content that is there is fairly solid and is quite well implemented with some nice modeling and animations on your enemies, very simple to understand buildign and material mechanics and simplified crafting systems making the mechanic a fun method of progressing rather than a tedious bore.

This is however where the good things about the game end as the amount of content currently avaiable is rather slim. Yes, there is a fairly nice variety of resources and structures you can build to defend your self from the incoming enemies, however you will find that the enemy variety it self is limited to a few monsters. The amount of things to do simply seems too small for the amount of time the game expects you to spend preparing for enemy attacks. Yes you can build up your defences, however I found that the amount of enemies that attack you at night is not big enough to pose a threat and while it might increase slowly over time, I found that its too slow allowing you to greatly outmatch the upcoming waves removing challenge from the equation.

To summarise, while the amount of content is fairly small, the quality of the content that is there is mostly outstanding. This game has a lot of potential, with the quality of the content thats there, I am having no doubpts about this game becoming something great. If you don't mind the lack of features, I'd say give it a go and see if you enjoy it your self.

Early Access Review

This game is a mix between first-person shooter, tower-defense, and sandbox-survival. This game is Minecaft with a Sanctum twist.

The game is as visually pleasing as it is fluid in movement. You have the parkour abilities necessary to climb almost anything, which makes the game a whole lot more interesting. You can wall-run and shoot down aliens that are attacking you and your base. The game is also very physics oriented which means destroying something from the base topples the entire structure.

So far I have only seen 3 aliens, but there might be more, since the game seems to be infinitely-generated. There are 2 weapons for the player to use, a pistol (which you start with) and an assault rifle. As for defending your 'Eden Kit' (which is your life-support), you can craft 4 (or 5, I can't remember) defensive structures. The game also has basic parts for making a base. On that note, building in this game works very well, I was able to adjust the orientation of everything I placed to whatever I needed.

From what I have read on the forums' this dev-team only releases updates when they are certain it is as far developed as possible, which makes for a far better play experience compared to indie titles that release buggier updates and simply fix them over time.

All-in-all this is an incredible title, all it is missing (in my opinion) is a multiplayer, which would make this one of my top 10 favorite games. I definitely recommend buying, and playing, this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Eden Star is another open world, survival and crafting game available in early access on Steam. But what separates it from the all the rest that are vying for your hard-earned money are some nice twists, a unique combat system, and a futurisitc sci-fi setting. (okay, GRAV has that last one but BitMonster,Inc really dropped the ball with their futuristic survival game)
It’s worth noting at this point that Eden Star is in a very early alpha state and that there is a LOT of content that needs to be added. At the moment I’d say that there’s about 2-4 hours worth of gameplay (depending how much you like base building). But even in its current state it's good fun, it has a solid gameplay foundation, and has a vast amount of potential. Moreover, the devs seem genuinely passionate about their creation, are continually keeping us updated with their plans and their progress, and are very good at replying to comments in the forums.

So, Eden Star has a unique combat system that involves grabbing enemies with your telekinetic device and then throwing them in a chosen direction. This brings no end of fun, as you can launch them soaring up high into the air only to have them plummet and splat back onto the ground several moments later (okay, the devs haven’t added a nice squishy “splat” yet). After grabbing you can also quickly turn around and cast individual aliens off a cliff and watch them disappear down into the misty abyss below, or (and my personal favourite) you can grab one alien bug and use it to smash another one in a truly delightful process that hasn’t ceased to amuse me.
In addition to the grab and smash approach, your equipment has an energy blast weapon that does exactly what it says to the alien creatures. This can be upgraded through unlocks to increase the power and duration of the blast so that it becomes a concentrated beam of searing energy. Thus adding another unique feature to this genre.
The final part of (the current) combat are the more traditional weapons (currently just a pistol and an assault rifle), which help to complete the FPS aspect of the game. (There’s a rather nice looking sniper rifle on the Eden Star drawing board, and there are plans for grenades too)

Harvesting resources is an essential part of the survival genre, and here Eden Star provides another variation on the theme. Instead of hacking away at rocks and trees with hammers and axes you use your energy harness tool to disintegrate and extract materials from their surroundings. Large rock formations slowly fall to pieces as the “tractor beam” wrenches them out of place and into your inventory.
It’s actually quite satisfying to watch a tree crumble under gravity and disintegrate in front of you as you harvest the materials and energy from it with your high-tech resource gathering tool. What makes this even greater is that you can upgrade this, as well, to make harvesting faster and also to allow you to perform it from a greater distance from the target material. I really do love the unlockable and upgradeable features they’ve included so far.

An interesting twist to the genre appears upon nightfall. Whereas Savage Lands brings a terribly bitter cold that forces you to seek shelter and huddle around a campfire to which you cling for dear life, and The Forest plunges you into true pitch black conditions in a hostile woodland, Eden Star brings something new to the table. As well as an increase in enemy activity (this is when you’ll be doing the most of your tower defence of your base) night time brings a potentially lethal exposure to radiation that compels you to withdraw and find refuge under the protective umbrella of your base’s energy shield. Keep an eye on the planet’s local time because you will need to get back to safety before you become fatally irradiated and/or before the hostile indigenous life rips your base to shreds.

Very briefly, the base building is excellent so far and seems to be a futuristic version of Rust. Eden Star allows you to build floors, walls, and ceilings separately so that you can construct your base exactly how you want it. No prefabricated rooms or buildings that constrict your creative freedom here!

Obviously, because this is still very early access I will be updating this review in the future after the devs have released significant updates. But for the time being I’m giving Eden Star a definite thumbs up!

Things I would like/need to see developed for the final game include:
- More action. Many more hostile life forms that are more threatening, thus deepening the FPS and tower defence aspects of the game to develop it into a true survival experience. The world is a little tame at the moment.
- More types of defence towers and the addition of traps to defend your base during the night time attacks.
- More fauna. Hostile, neutral, and friendly to enhance the feeling of the environment and the immersive atmosphere.
- More geological feature. E.g. caves, water systems, impassable cliffs, geothermal pits, volcanoes - again to improve the environment further and to provide some unique locations for exploration.
- Some sort of story and quests (i.e. an end game scenario). E.g. destroy all enemy life to make the planet habitable for your race to colonise. Or survive long enough to build a shuttle to escape from the hostile world on which you’ve been stranded. These are just my ideas.


*** 21st December 2015 Update ***

- A new energy blade melee weapon (that's rather reminiscent of Star War's light sabres). This is really good fun to use, it sounds absolutely fantastic (although quite a few ingame sounds are still buggy), and it really adds to the futuristic setting of Eden Star.
- Two new enemies, the best of which is a particularly agressive flying creature that will suicide bomb attack your eden kit if you're not careful. It'll also dive attack you as well, knocking you back quite a distance. This can easily push you outside the shield of your eden kit thereby exposing you to the lethal night time radiation, or even worse, can propel you off a cliff to instant death. Be careful how you fight them!
- Multiplayer!!! Both coop and PvP!


For more information on current progress and future plans, check out what the devs post on trello.com, and as always leave questions here and I'll get back to you.

Happy surviving, and remember: if you do die, be sure to clean up the mess please.

This is an Early Access review of Eden Star. This review will contain what I've learned from my 15+hrs of playing the game.

Eden Star is, currently, an Early Access game about a character who crashes on an alien planet and must find specific parts from an object called the Eden Kit. The tutorial gives you everything you need to know on how to play the game from start to finish.

The game is created through the Unreal 4 Engine. The engine has great potential, and the developers have given the game rather nice texures for obvious reasons.

You begin the game falling from the sky and landing in a pod of some kind. As the door shoots open you are greeted to the alien planet along with a fiery sky show of fallen ship parts. Your goal is to go and retrieve an Eden Kit to call your home.

After building a base out of trees, rocks and other minerals you can gather, it should soon be night time. Edited: This is one of the most helpful reviews on the page, so I cleaned it up a bit and added more stuff.

Eden Star is one of those few early access titles that I've bought into. I generally stay away from them, apart from a few exceptions, and Eden Star is one of them. It caught my eye as a survival game with more of a base-building/tower defence focus, in which you gather resources and build your base and defences during the day, and defend it during the night.

You start off with an Eden Kit and some resources, and you have until night to find a decent spot for your base. The base-building is quite versatile, and as long as you have the resources, you can create the base that you want to properly defend your Eden Kit.

The Eden Kit is what protects you from this planet's toxic night air. If you go outside it's protective shield (which can be upgraded to increase it's radius) at night time, you start taking damage, and will eventually die. This makes defending it a top priority, and since the creatures that inhabit this world have taken a personal offence to your giant shield, defend it you must, as they will attack in swarms at night.

This of course means combat, and it starts off as fairly standard, with a variety of guns and a melee weapon in case you run out of ammo. However, some upgrades to your MATA tool (essentially it's what allows you to harvest, build, etc), and you can basically become a jedi with an energy sword, and the ability to push and grab enemies and hurl them at whatever you want (this can also be chained, provided you don't hurl them outside grabbing range).

Now, they may be cool to watch and everything, but they're just a gimmick right? Just shooting enemies is surely a lot easier? Well, in short, no. First off, the grab ability (the most useful and fun to watch) is tied in with your MATA tool's harvesting, so you don't have to bother switching to your gun. So depending on what you're pointing the reticle at, you can either harvest or kill. It's more of a convenience thing, but one I like. The second (and more important) benefit is that it saves on inventory space. Ammo for guns takes up inventory slots, so the more ammo you bring along for your trip, the less space you have to carry the resources you need.

This means the non-gun options actually provide a tangible benefit to using them, since they don't require the ammo that guns do (although the push does require energy, but that is something completely separate and doesn't take up inventory space). And apart from all that, it's hilarious to grab an enemy, smash him into a rock, then fling him up into the sky.

Right now, it is fairly light on content, and as you'd expect of an early access game, there are some bugs, glitches and crashes (although I personally haven't had a single crash), and I can always tell when a horde of enemies is about to attack my base at night, since the framerate dips fairly noticeably.

However, I do have to say, the devs are doing a fantastic job with this game. They're passionate and dedicated, and I have no doubt they'll make this game the best they possibly can. They're incredibly transparent, regularly posting updates on what they're working on, and the vast majority of forum posts are answered by them personally. Ultimately, this is what convinced me to buy Eden Star, and if you like the concept and the direction of this game, you should too.

Early Access Review

Eden Star is a fantastic game, and the direction it is being taken in is one I can whole-heartedly support. I've backed numerous Survival EA games, and this one by far is the best one I've backed so far.

You're dropped in an escape pod onto an alien planet, where the nights become so toxic they can kill you. The aliens on the planet do not like your being there, and attack you. You have your MATA-Tool on your hand to gather materials and build, but that's the extent of what you have in the beginning.

You get an Eden Kit, which provides power and a shield to keep you safe at night. The aliens do not like the Eden Kit, and will attack it, becoming more aggressive as time goes on. Collecting materials, you have to craft with them to build your base to keep you and your Eden Kit safe from hostilities. You can craft a multitude of different blocks, turrets with different attributes, and utilities like doors and generators.

You can also use what you have gathered to upgrade your suit, make weapons (assault rifle, pistol, sniper rifle, submachine gun) and to craft ammo, of which you can make different types.

There are three biomes, with more planned. They are hand-crafted and well detailed, with different advantages and disadvantages.

The aliens you encounter will all be different, from little splintermites crawling around like pests to a bird that likes to ♥♥♥♥ you off and steal the materials you're working on gathering.

They recently introduced multiplayer, which is basic for now, but has a colony system to allow people to group together.

The game runs on Unreal Engine 4, and the graphics are fantastic compared to other EA titles I've seen in the Survival genre.

The developers also release consistent blog development updates about the game, what they are working on, what they are fixing, and each individual person working on the game gives a short snippet of what they are currently focused on.

All in all it's a great game, great concept, great execution, all done by a great and vocal development team.

Early Access Review

March 12, 2016 - Pre-Alpha

TLDR
Pros
+Beautiful Environment
+Smooth, flexible character mobility
+Simple gathering system
+Build a base, defend at night

Cons
-Combat feels unsatisfying
-Extremely limited base building options
-No sense of progression (resources / monsters)

Verdict
While the simplicity of it all is satisfying at first, you'll soon wonder what on earth you'll do next to keep things interesting.

Full Review
After over a year in Early Access, I expected more.

I played the game for an hour, built everything there was to build, and tasted a few nights of combat. Some people are giggly wiggly over the fact that you can grab the monsters from afar and toss them around; I feel that overall, combat just isn't satisfying. Your weapons feel like crap; when you hit something, it'd be nice to have some feedback / recoil / monster recoiling / Something! Even the meelee doesn't work so well; half the time, you will automatically target a dead monster instead of the live one right next to it. What irks me even more is that monsters have no loot, in a world full of things to be looted.

Indeed, if combat isn't so great, this type of game often falls back on creativity via building stuff, and exploration. I found however, that I could build everything right away! The resources aren't hard to find, or challenging to get; there's no sense of progression. I can't venture to a more dangerous area to retrieve a rare material to build a cooler turret to defend against a stronger monster. I can't discover more advanced tools or machines for my base, to fill it up with; I can just build a bigger base to fill up with a maximum of 3 types of turrets - and there isn't even an explanation of what differentiates them from one another.

I really wanted to love this game, and was excited to play it, but after an hour, all that's left to do is build more iron foundations and walls, more of the 1 model power generator, more eden kits, more of the same 3 turrets, and watch it all take down more monsters at night. Inevitably, I will fall off another cliff along the way, or die inexplicably outside my front door, and lose all my gathered materials again.

Perhaps in another year the game will be more fleshed out and start to resemble a final product; for now, all that can be done is play around with the mechanics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDEN STAR is what you get when Rust/H1Z1/survival games have a beautiful baby with gems such as Lost Planet 2, Titanfall, and more.

There are so many wonderful ideas. From base construction, crafting, to automated defenses and a meaningful day/night cycle. But it doesn't stop there. Wall running parkour, grappling/riding enemies, unique abilities, and they are working on automatons to help you fight entire wars against other player factions.

The game is pre-alpha, but I would buy it again. The dev team posts updates practically weekly, and provide a level of transparency that is on par with or beyond even the famously open Star Citizen. They speak to us, and they have a personal relationship with the community. Unlike so many big corporations that follow strict PR guidelines, this is a group of people that know their audience, people who have soul, and most of all dedication: this is obviously a project of passion for everyone involved.

That really does meaning something, because gamers as consumers really care about the brands they play. They do have a more personal relationship with the creators and company than other consumers do. A game isn't like flour: I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about the flour or who supplies it, so long as it isn't wood pulp and it's reasonably priced. But games are something I may spend hundreds to thousands of hours on. They are something people care about and grow to love. That's why gamers are notoriously fickle: because they're passionate. They want to see a game be everything that it can be, and they see the company and developers as *partners* in that endeavor. But most game companies have not caught on to this, and still treat it like any other customer-business relationship

But not Flix Interactive. They understand the nature of their relationship with us. To have a game company actually listening and communicating is a breath of fresh air. There is no silence to make you nervous, there are no worries about if you're being heard or what's going on. You know. And they don't just talk to you. They listen. They take player feedback. For instance, players wanted to build huge bases, even cities. This was never planned for or intended. Do you know what they did? They began optimizing the game for accomodate large structures as best as they could. The idea for drones and fighting robots arose from this, and it's why they're developing it; it all came back to the players wanting large settlements, and those settlements needed defenders.

With all that said, the game is a pre-alpha. Performance is not exceptional, though over the last patch it has improved immensely in my opinion. The movement is janky at times, the UI is kinda buggy now and then, and it has its mechanical problems. But that's how it goes with a pre-alpha.

But as a cynical consumer, skeptical and disillusioned with a distant game industry stuffed with the same recycled material, this is a game that stands apart. This surely sounds like a contradiction, as the market is being flooded with survival games. Is this a survival game? Yes, absolutely. But it is not confined by that genre: it builds on it with great ideas. This is a game I can love with a dev team I can believe in.

If you are something of a gaming philanthrophist, then let me say now: if there was ever a game that deserved your money, it is this one. If for whatever reason, you don't want to spend money on it in its current state, that's fair. But be sure to check back every few months. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

If you want to see the future plans, what is being worked on at present, and what has been added, take a look at the trello board here: https://trello.com/b/dmyocCtO/eden-star-public-board

Players can vote on what they'd like to see added next, provide feedback, and provide ideas. The devs are also active on steam, and have a subreddit which at the moment is practically just updates and patch notes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Eden Star is a game with potential. Big potential. Fun, engaging, and challenging I recommend it. That said, in its current state it is A) little more than clean functioning fundamentals and B) A base defense game at it's core. It may be one of the most immersive, pretty, and well crafted tower defense games but it is still about hustling to get the materiel you need and craft (and place) the items you need before night falls and all hell breaks loose.

Things to Know:
The game is functional, very functional right now. Limited in scope (maybe 10 hours of fun right now, big patch coming soon), but plays like a final game.
The dev's have addressed past problems such as no save system (still waiting on randomly generated worlds)
The game seems well thought out, and the content they plan to add will be what fills out the potential of the game.


Conclusions
Most of the early release games on steam are steaming piles of crap, Eden Star seems different. The game as it currently  stands is the most playable and functional Early Access games I have ever played. The game plan of the future, adding more content, such as new building options, defenses, items, and enemies is exactly what this game needs  to make it great....and that is just the start of what they plan. I check my updates every day waiting for the April patch, and i cannot remember the last time I was so eager for a game update.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is an interesting one. The whole thing revolves around a basic tower defense principal, where you build and protect your Eden Kit from hostile native species, because you're the invading alien and they don't like you. Beyond the possibility of some shoehorned social-political commentary or some such, this game is actually pretty good.

The combat system is responsive and fun and you have to pay attention to pretty much every enemy so you don’t get pinned into a corner. The parkour system helps with this, allowing you to do a bit of guerilla warfare by running up with your Gauss Cannon, hitting a hive for a few seconds, before running back off into the trees and away from the hordes of enemies. You can and will augment your personal arsenal of firearms and energy weapons with turrets placed around your base to keep away the night time raids. The turrets are fairly basic, as there’s currently only 3 types, missile, auto (machine gun), and laser. You also have to manage power levels in your base, each turret takes some power, and each generator adds some power to the pool. I’m not terribly far in this game yet, so I’m not sure if there’s a practical limit on turrets.

A big part of this game is the building system. As far as I know, your structures won’t collapse in Red factions style if you build them poorly (I hope that gets added in at some point) but if you’re not careful, you’ll eventually get a message telling you that you cannot place XYZ at that location because your structure is weak. This can get a bit annoying when trying to build a bridge, but I appreciate the realism. In order to build structures, you’ll need to strap on your big boy pants and venture out into the wilderness to collect resources. Each structure, as far as I know, can be built out of different base materials, depending on what you have or what you need. For example, an Ironite base is the strongest, but Ironite can be a bit annoying to come by, especially early in game if you don’t know where to look. So, instead of Ironite, you can build with Bridgmanite (no idea if I spelled that right) and take a slight dip in health to stock up on Ironite. Or, you may have a small Ironite structure protecting your Eden Kit, with a larger Bridgmenite fortification. Most weapons and modules can also be built from 2 or 3 base materials, which allows you to ration supplies more effectively.

Storage is a big problem in this game. If there’s a storage container that isn’t your Eden Kit, I haven’t found it. The Eden Kit has 5 material storage slots, and each of those can hold a stack of 300 of one material. This is fine at first, until you’re going out and coming back with your inventory full, because you didn’t use all your bullets the previous night. Your character has an inventory of 10 slots, each able to hold a max of 300 of one raw material, much like the Eden Kit, the place where this gets a bit iffy, is that ammo only stacks to a certain amount, I think around 144 per slot (which sounds like a lot until you get mobbed by 20 enemies and you begin to fire wildly into the crowd).

The last thing I want to say is just little things I like about the game. The physics in this game are amazing. Pretty much any material node can be deconstructed into physics particles (except for large boulders, which just fuzz out of existence if you try to cut them into smaller pieces). As you mine, collectable materials will spawn and then despawn as you absorb them. PSA though, don’t stand on top of what you’re mining, because there’s a rare chance that the game will flip its ♥♥♥♥ with the physics objects and launch you into the air. The environments, are beautiful, with each biome having different resource nodes that give you different materials. As far as I know, and I haven’t done any extensive exploration, the basic biomes are: Desert, Forest, and Swamp, with a nice blending where they border each other. Each biome will have its own sort of special resource nodes that will give you a specific material, so you’ll eventually need to branch out and explore to get a decent stockpile.

So yeah, this game is pretty good so far, pretty solid gunplay, a decent parkour system, and it seems to have a lot of polish for an early access game. There isn’t a lot of depth to it yet, but I think I can see where they’ve left room to add that later, with time and more updates.

Early Access Review

As of v0.0.1, Eden Star has a tendency to crash on my system at the frequency of roughly 1 hour into the game, and there is no means to save, so there's no real persistence to my efforts as of yet.   Still, it's a pretty solid start to a really cool take to the whole construction-survival-sim.

Core to the coolness of this game is how you are wearing a suit that lets you break down trees and rocks in a realistic fashion, they pop and break as you work, the power of a micro singularity at your fingertips, so you can scoop the matter up in some sort of matter digitizer and take it back to your Eden platform in order to build construction blocks, turrets, and weapons.  This suit can also be upgraded to become a full on grav gun, picking up and throwing enemies and other objects, as well as a rail gun upgrade.  It's a great platform to play with 3D engine physics, although it keeps everything above ground (no digging) and it's mostly just rocks and trees and aliens right now.

Making progess involves upgrading your Eden platform by converting resources into energy but, the more energy your Eden platform has, the more attention of the hostile wildlife it attracts.  As there is nothing to do but upgrade your Eden platform, in theory, things will slowly but steadily ramp up from being a leisurely walk to a desperate fight to hold your ground.  In action, it's very barebones right now, the attacking wildlife comes in slowly, sometimes not at all and, just when things are starting to get interesting, the game crashes or locks up (your mileage may vary; my system might be less compatible than yours).  Lacking a means to save the game, I am sent back to the beginning.

But it is certainly a pretty interesting tech demo for as long as it lasts, and I hope the developers see through their vision instead of losing motivation, pocketing the early access money and running as some do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So to start of. For a pre-alpha game it's very impressive.

Concept: The concept is very interesting. At times feels like a fps
with some satisfying weapons (currently pistol, SMG, Rifle, Sniper, Baton, Energy Baton)
and then feels like a 3D mine craft.
The build system is very similar to fallout 4 in terms of snapping objects etc..
but atm, as it is pre-alpha, doesnt have content (basic structural components, 3 types of turret and a few utilities, power gen etc..)


FPS: FPS wise it's pretty solid having been built with Unreal Engine 4.
Weapons have satisfying models and sounds and the enemies are varied enough to
require different tactics not just spamming rifle. You can also upgrade you
mining tool to project kinetic blasts for knock back and through upgrades
add furhter knock-back, damage, projected laser etc.. to make combat much
more varied. Feels sort of like a fantasy RPS with both guns and magicks.

Enemies: There are a select few differnt types of enemies that spawn at certain sites,
destroying the hive while enemies attack is challanging and rewarding (rare ore telirium?)
On a night they attack your base and if you don't take care of the hive the attacks
become worse, sustaining damage to walls,defenses and your EDEN kit.


Movement: I really like the parkour in this game. Very satisfying to be acble to scale rock faces with
the ability to actually reach ledges significatly higher than you.

Mining: Mining is cool. Holding the right mouse strips ore deposits and
trees with a nice context menu telling u the compisition of different minearls.
THe mining can also be upgraded to either be faster, reach futher or enhance combat by paralysing enemies and
then throwing them etc..

Graphics: Very nice graphics as expected form unreal engine 4. Lighting is a bit
odd for me (could just be me) but the light and dark areas can be too high contrast at times.
However as pre-alpha this isn't something I would hold against the DEVS.

Mulitplayer: Not done multiplayer yet but the devs have some pretty good looking guides for
setting up a server.

Upgrading and construction: The upgrades and construction require certain minerals/ores
as a base cost and some allow you to choose the aditional ore/mineral. This allows
you to play stategically in what ores/minerals you have to spare etc..
basic structures like walls etc. can be made using a select few, some way more common than others
but the rarer minerals/ores add bonuses / debuffs to HP heat resistance etc... which is a nice
touch. Equipment wise upgrades for your mining tool, kinetic force, repair tools requires both specific minerals/ores
and additional. Ammo is made at the Eden Kit so you have to work for your ammo, again a nice touch.

Development: The devs seem very pasionate about this game and what they've promised
to include looks like this game could become very popular.

Future prospects: Once more content is added, simple structures, utilties, defenses etc and more upgrades
I think this game could be a real hit. I can forsee large multiplayer servers with factions etc..
in a PVE environment. Differnt builds such as Heavy hitters, expert miners, expert navigators etc, crowd controllers..
Bosses should be an interesting feature in terms of reward etc..

Here are some of the features in dev at the time of this review:

16km island, should be very interesting
Boss like enemies
Explosive weapons - will like to see how much the ammo drains ur resources
More buildables
Creature creation - should be fun
Vehicles - Yes please!

and some features planned:

more melee - would be cool to see upgrades
upgradeable armour - very nice, shield upgrades? regen, damage etc...
More utilities - not just power generators
caves - would be awesome builing in a cave with a heavly fortified front
robotic allies - customisable would be awesome

My thoughts: Been a space age open world builder, I would like to see some advance structures and
the ability to change fine details etc.. no doubt someone will try and build a death star. Things like teleport stations so u can set up microbases in distant locations.
Jump pads to cross chasms, surveying tools, maybe bots that go out to survey where good

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7/10 for this EA Survival game [multiplayer, coop & single-player].

Against the back-drop of several half-baked Early Access Survival games that aren't worth the asking price (except Dont Starve, Ark and Wurm Unlimited), this game certainly has a very unique and fresh spin on the genre, and it is very very actively supported by the devs, while it runs very smoothly.

So, It feels to me like an open-world sci-fi survival game with a uniqe environmental tower-defence element to it.  Like Don't Starve, you take advantage of the day cycle to mine, scrounge, explore for resources, and build and adventure.  While at night, you defend your expanding base in a hostile environment that is also toxic at night, being a key component to the survival element.

There is quite a ways to go with the content (redundancy of game-play and lack of wiki-game play development) , but having passed on other survival games, I have read, watched and feel this one is something special; at least can be more-so as necessary content is added.

Again, my biggest con, which is understandable is content needs to be pushed into the game so it has more to offer than just repetitive building and base improving, such as more to explore, travel and value in defeating mobs.  For example, I just logged because of lack of wiki content while looking for material information that provides info on game-play content & mechanics was just irritating me too much.

Sci-Fi Minecraft, which is great, and if the problems I am going to mention are eliminate, then this is a must have, but so far I think its a neutral with great potential. Mind you this is still in early access, so I can forgive the devs for some of the problems.

The game features a pre designed world with multiple biomes fill with neutral and aggressive creatures. You need to build a base to survive the night, because during night, the atmosphere turns toxic and you are only protected from the toxicitity by your base. During day time you can gather materials and use it to build floors and walls, defence turrents, generators, or use it to craft upgrades, weapons, and ammo. The world is huge, but generic, which is disappointing, but never the less, still great.

There are some crucial problems though - motion sickness. For a survival base-building game, it is a killer problem to have motion sickness, and although motion sickness may not apply to everyone, from my experience, it hurts my brain. In a survival base-building game, you expect players to grind and run all around the place for a long duration, and so motion sickness will accumulate and just hurt the player physically, which is just terrible. A suggestion from me will be adjust the audio, and also make sure when gathering materials, the debris don't fly into the camera. Soften the colorful effects for material gathering, the bright color flashing around hurts the eye.

Pros:
-Great survival building game, challenging, but not too punishing
-Like Minecraft, has great potential in the building aspect
-More combat than Minecraft
-Turrets :)
-Still just Early Access, and already amazing
-Decent graphics

Cons:
-Minor bugs
-Generic environment
-Motion sickness (for me at least)
-Expensive?
-Would be better to have materials scattered after death, rather than have the player lose all their materials. The Minecraft approach would be nice here

Overall:
Give it a go if you have the bucks, keep an eye on this bad ♥♥♥ though, can be the next big thing :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game with a lot of potential, currently still early in its development cycle... and it shows at times.

THE UPSIDE:

I was really drawn to the sort of 'mass effect' feel in a survival game.  Even the tool you use to mine, craft, build or fight reminded me of an 'omni-tool', as do the weapons.  Survival games are so frequently based around the sword and board ages or... gah... zombies, this game presented a much welcomed alternative to those flavors.

The game looks beautiful and the mechanics seem well polished and in fairly good working order, particularly when you take the development point of the game into account.


THE DOWNSIDE:

There are two major problems with the game right now and both are likely to change as development continues... i hope.

The first as i see it, the game is extremely shallow.  While everything you can do works well and looks pretty good, you can do just about all of it within a few hours of play.  You can always make your base larger and more elaborate and you can always farm for more materials, but beyond that survival is never really an issue after the first few turrets are placed down.  That isn't to say there isn't something enjoyable about building elaborate structures and seeing just how difficult you can make it for another player to get into your base, but right now you are pretty limited by type/number of things you can build.

The second major flaw in the system right now, and really i can't stress this enough, the server system is an exercise in pure frustration.  As it stands right now, you join a server and maybe you even took the time to visit the forums and find out which servers are most reliable".  Even among these your doing well if your server is up more than two or three days in a row without disappearing for that at least that long.  You can switch servers of course and restart your base again... and then you can do it again when this server vanishes... and again... and honestly if you do it again you kind of deserve what you get.

Largely for this reason multiplayer is a pretty lonely existence.  Rarely more than 2-3 people are ever on the supposedly "most reliable" servers.  And its fairly easy to understand why.

One confusing mechanic was that while all servers are listed as PVE
date: they are most certainly not.  By accident my friends and I had found our way into another base and were shocked to find we were able to access their resources.  We actually were somewhat pleased at this revelation because while i'm not sure its intended it meant the game had radically new meaning.  We had to rebuild our base to defend against players!  And we were going to gear up and venture out and see what other bases we could crack.  This was quite a lot of fun
recommended: but then enter the extreme unreliability of the servers
hoursPlayed:
to say nothing of the general confusion as to the PVE/PVP status of those servers.


THE LOWDOWN:  6.0/10  *with a lot of potential

For someone who doesn't usually look twice at survival games this one really caught my attention.  It has a lot going for it and i really hope the development process continues along the very promising lines it seems to be.  If your truly are looking for a single player survival experiences (WHY?) then a lot of the issues i have with the game really don't impact you

UPDATE 8. October 2015:

Still gonna give my thumbs up for this game, the new additions (more upgrades, a new biome, heavily improved building UI including new buildings, new enemy AI including perception and improved pathing, new foliage system that improves performance and makes forests more dense) make sense and the game still runs way too smooth for an alpha. game: 8.5/10 (not too much to do, but it's an alpha dammit), graphics 9/10, potential 17/10


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Eden Star is an early-access game with a sci-fi setting. It belongs to the genres of sandbox, ego-shooter and has roleplay elements.

So, first off, this game is in a very early early state and most of the gameplay is not implemented, this review is based on the 0.04 pre-alpha update.

I can only speak positive of this game so far, the stability is frightening for a game in a this early state, I only encountered 4 crashes so far and the FPS are stable (i7, 760gtx), the game runs on Unreal Engine 4. The graphics are really good, feel well composed and the art-style is appealing(imo).

Now let's come to the gameplay aspect: Some upgrades are already in, 3 weapons and basic construction. Most of it feels well implemented, it just seems that the devs know exactly what they want, this is not some project of some unorganized garage-devs(*huh*starforge*huhhuhu*). Shooting is still a bit inaccurate. The cool thing is the power of UE4, resource mining feels really awesome and the world is really immersive. The fighting is based on shooting and using your tools like lifting enemies and samshing them into the ground, all paired with parcours elements and wallrunning.

So, EDEN STAR has a lot of potential, but we still have to see how it will become but it definitely has better chances of becoming something. The devs are also very responsive and explain why they implement what.

Not worth the $20 I paid for the existing content.

For $5, sure, its not a bad early access, but as it is there isnt near enough for me to feel like I didnt just waste my money.
Maybe over the next year it will earn its price tag.

What they have so far is in some ways solid. The graphics are decent enough and the effects look nice. Combat feels right. Traversing the landscape is fast and fun without the worries of many survival games such as eating, stamina, or realistic fall damage.
The first thing I noticed that felt incomplete was a general lack of sound. No music, very little movement sound effects, and this crazy glowing thing on your hand that rips trees down and pulls boulders apart makes almost no sound at all. You only only hear the actual target getting shredded.
Speaking of the harvesting/collecting, at its core it is fun. You can take out the bottom of a tree and watch it fall in various ways with nice physics and such.

I know this is early access, so missing sounds and the only 2 extremely generic enemies I saw is understandable, but once you get the hang of the build system (took me about 20 minutes) you are just gathering, building a base with very limited options, watching/helping your turrets kill the 2 bad guy types, then rinse and repeat. The difficulty ramps up each night as you improve your base. You can save and try different approaces to getting through a night, and you can respawn if you have a certain ore on your base gained by destroying enemy nests. Die without any ore, game over, reload last save.

I got base built up and had about all the fun there was to have in about 3 hours, and I can't say that fun was real exciting or special.

This is another early access where I would wait and see whet the devs have in store for it instead of paying too much for a general draft of the game's basics. I do see potential though.

Early Access Review

A bare bones and flawed game on a solid concept and design foundation.

I've only spent on hour in the game so far on the day of initial E.A. release.  The controls are great as are the graphics.  But, right now, it doesn't really feel like a game per se.  You have about 6 minutes of daylight to run around and zap trees and rocks, then about 6 minutes of night to zap bugs.  The bugs seem to just warp in under my feet as well.  The daytime doesn't seem to be long enough to really dig into any kind of building or exploring and nighttime is a tower defense mini game.

Some suggestions to what's currently in game (not additional features):

Harvesting trees makes visual sense.  I can see the tree fall and break into pieces.  And they take a comfortable amount of time to do so.  Harvesting rocks is a visual mess and takes far longer.  Perhaps tightening up the visual clues of what's left in a rock to harvest or something to clue me into the progress would be helpful.  Also, since I only have abou 6 solid minutes of daylight, spending 2 of them on a rock is extremely limiting.

The bug alien critters seem to just pop out of nowhere.  I'm not sure if that's a bug (no pun intended) or that's how they work.  It was odd to be turning around looking for these things and they just pop in under my feet.  Perhaps if they originated from their little dens or mounds and skittered toward me.

They day/night cycle time is very rushed.  Right now, I feel like the game can't decide if it wants to be a exploration/construction game or a tower defense.  It has aspects of both, but they are hampered.  And one major way is the short time windows.  Let me explore and harvest a little longer and actually have some time to build something and maybe have some kind of build up at night, the pacing and number of bugs attacking increases or comes in waves instead of the static two pop in at a time in exact intervals.


Overall, I think the presentation of the game is solid.  The help pop ups are clear and understandable.  The graphics are nice and the art direction has its own identity.  I think there's more foundation in this game than many E.A. games in terms of setting, design, and concept.  It certainly has a long way to go, and I'm excited to follow it as it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of 0.0.3, this game has limitless potential. Most of the mechanics work pretty good and the game is very much playable. I found myself becomming disinterested mostly because the mobs don't spawn fairly (seems around the third night they just come at you faster than you can take them down. Frame rate issues also make this harder), and you can't take down defenses once they are put up; you have to wait for them to be destroyed. I'm sure that will be fixed later. If you really enjoy farming for supplies and stick around to play a game after getting a good idea of what the game is about, then you'll enjoy this. I look forward to coming back in a month and seeing what has changed.

P.S- $20 is a bit heavy for the game at this point. If you have a small gaming budget I would wait a little while and pick up something more complete.

Early Access Review

First experience - liked it for an early access game and hope to see a lot more development. So recommended as it is playable to a point even at this early stage.

Obviously there's still plenty to get done. Incredibly short day/night cycles annoyed me immensely and i hope this is something that can be adjusted later on. Losing all of my inventory on death was frustrating too. Spending time gathering and then becoming swamped by a nest was down to my own fault as I wasn't paying much attention as to where i was going (lost inv was still annoying regardless).

Overall though I wish I had waited a while longer before buying but I can see this game being one worth buying.
